When I was in botball, we had a "pre-season" that was basically botball tryouts. While the new students were being taught what botball is and how to use a Wallaby (Wombats didn't exist yet), we would go and design a gameboard for them using the pieces from previous years. Then the new members got split up into teams and competed against each other.

If I was a teacher doing a robotics class I would probably design periodic challenges with them and use that as assignments/extra credit for the class.

If you do implement a pre-season, I would recommend trying very hard to make the team leader(s) understand that they should choose who gets in based on effort and not on skill. Skill based selection got out of hand and evolved into a toxic learning environment (it also defeats the point of botball, which is to give students skills). When my generation became leaders we switched to effort based and had new members sign a behavior contract, the bullying issues seemed to have stopped.
<@502520219990753280> or donate them to a good cause (Norman Advanced Robotics) :)

Divide your students up into groups and give them each some of the pieces. Then everyone can make their own mini challenge for everyone else to try. I did that once and it was a fun way to spend time during the off season.

It depends on what the sound sensor would be used for.

If we are wanting voice recognition, I believe most of the libraries for that will do the filtering for you, but I've never worked on it myself.
If we are just detecting for a specific frequency, but the student should be able to select the frequency, we could do a digital bandpass or notch filter using the FFT.
If we just want a specific frequency so the bots could start using a sound instead of light, we could do a hardware filter.

Hardware filters are better when you are able to use them because all you need is a resistor and a capacitor/inductor (usually capacitors because they operate better for high frequency and have a much smaller package size).

I think your logic is correct. if you assume that each cube that touches black tape is a bottommost **item ** (as you mentioned) in a stack then each of those constitutes the possible start of a stack and thus a separate scoring area. Therefore any cube that touches the top of it can be a part of it's stack. Although a stack is not sorted if there are two cubes on top of one where at least one is not the same color as one of the one below it. So examples below:

Sorted:   GR       G        R
                 GR      G       GR

Not Sorted:    GR      R
                          G       G

Since Botguy scores in the transporter and the side he can only score in one of those areas and he scores in whichever is highest with out multipliers, i.e. the transporter. However, scoring is different than the multiplier. The case we are using to consider this is rulings we have made on cubes previously. Cubes can cause a transporter to be sorted but still score on the black tape lines. So if we are applying similar reasoning here, Botguy can score and sort the transporter but also multiply things on the side, he just can't score in both areas. The same situation could be applied to the sample isolation and the robot staging.

Just as a general update for anyone asking rules based questions here on Discord. This is just a reminder that Discord is not the official FAQ and for a response to be considered official for a competition, it needs to be asked on the FAQ on the team homebase. If I am the one judging a competition as the head judge you can expect I will probably make a judgement at the competition the same as how I have answered it on here but if it is someone else it may need to be mentioned on the official FAQ for them to defer to that.
You can do a lot of interesting things with the Create OI. Would recommend playing around with it.

<@845445392870277131> see the Create 2 OI documentation PDF for information: https://edu.irobot.com/learning-library/create-2-oi-spec-1

On page 19 you'll see the Song command. You can use `create_write_byte` in libwallaby to write raw Create OI commands over the serial connection.

An example (untested, written in discord):

```c

#include <kipr/wombat.h>

// A struct allows us to store multiple variables in a single variable.
// A note is composed of two integers (note and duration). We can then pass
// around these notes between functions.
typedef struct
{
  // Note number (see create OI PDF)
  // An `unsigned char` is an integer value between 0 and 255 (inclusive).
  unsigned char note;
  // Duration in increments of 1/64th a second
  unsigned char duration;
} Note;

int write_song(
  // The song ID on the create
  unsigned char song_number,
  // The actual song. An array of notes.
  const Note *const notes,
  // Number of notes.
  // An `unsigned int` is a integer value between 0 and 2^32-1
  unsigned int length
)
{
  // Song number must be 0 to 4
  if (song_number > 4)
  {
    // We failed
    return 0;
  }

  // length must be 1 to 16
  if (length < 1 || length > 16)
  {
    // We failed
    return 0;
  }

  // Opcode 140 denotes a song command
  create_write_byte(140);

  // Write song number
  create_write_byte(song_number); 

  // Write song length
  create_write_byte(length);

  // Iterate through the notes, writing them out one by one
  unsigned int note_iterator = 0;
  for (note_iterator = 0; note_iterator < length; note_iterator += 1)
  {
    const Note *const note = notes[note_iterator];
    // Write note
    create_write_byte(note->note);
    // Write duration
    create_write_byte(note->duration);
  }

  // Success!
  return 1;
}

int play_song(unsigned char song_number)
{
  if (song_number > 4)
  {
    // Invalid song_number
    return 0;
  }

  // Opcode 141 is play
  create_write_byte(141);
  // Write song number
  create_write_byte(song_number);

  return 1;
}

int main()
{
  // Our song
  Note notes[2] = {
    {
      // A#
      .note = 46,
      // 1 second
      .duration = 64
    },
    {
      // C#
      .note = 49,
      .duration = 128,
    }
  };

  create_connect();

  // Write song 0 containing 2 notes
  int success = write_song(0, notes, 2);
  if (success == 0)
  {
    // Tell the user we failed
    printf("Failed to write song!\n");
    // exit
    create_disconnect();
    return 0;
  }

  // play the song (see Create OI PDF)
  success = play_song(0);
  if (success == 0)
  {
    printf("Failed to play song!\n");
    create_disconnect();
    return 0;
  }

  // You might need to wait for the song
  // to finish before disconnecting... not sure.
  msleep(4000);


  create_disconnect();
  return 0;
}
```

<@!946193333615734794> We have not made a video of it and I don't have a close up picture of it but I can get one on Friday when we do construction for the Northern California tournament. The way we have found that works best after setting up one tournament now is: 
1. Align one coupler to an edge of the acrylic that is laying flat on a surface and center the edge of the acrylic along the center of length of the coupler.
2. Then using one piece of tape, attach the coupler to the acrylic. 
3. Repeat this for the other 3 couplers.
4. Flip the assembly over, the acrylic will still be wobbly on the couplers.
5. Realign the acrylic edge so it is once again centered on the length of a coupler and apply a piece of tape, making sure that the tape does not leave much room for the coupler to move.
6. Repeat this for the other 3 couplers, adding additional tape as needed at the end to make sure it doesn't wobble too much.

The problem is that the way you calculate an accurate battery percentage in a device like a phone is by creating what is a called a battery discharge curve. However, the curve is slightly different even between two seemingly identical batteries from the same manufacturer. The way your smartphone gets around that is by updating it's battery discharge curve with new data that it collects while running normally. That is why sometimes you can make your phone have a more accurate percentage by making it drain itself completely dead from 100% and then charging it back to 100%.

Our controller has a battery discharge curve model that is used in the percentage shown, but there is no way to implement active adjustment because the battery is swapped so often. Additionally the current charge is calculated on the current voltage from the battery. When the battery has a significant load such as motors, the voltage will drop giving the Wombat an incorrect battery level. There are ways we could implement a more accurate reading, but it would add significant cost and the goal of botball is to get as many students involved as possible.

This usually means your filesystem has gotten corrupted somehow. Every so often a team will come to me with this problem, but I've never had it happen to me and I haven't been able to recreate it in the lab so I'm not sure what I can recommend to avoid it. 

My best guess is that users are turning off their Wombat (or their battery dies) while the Wombat is accessing the SD card (compiling, creating programs, etc). 
That's why we tell people to use the shutdown button, even though most of the time it's not going to matter if you just flip the switch.

To fix the problem you will have to swap or rewrite your SD card.
Your options are:
- Send it in and have us swap the SD card for you (dm me, email support@kipr.org, or email me directly at zsasser@kipr.org to set that up)
- Take the SD card out and follow some instructions I have and rewrite the image yourself (requires an SD reader, but isn't very difficult)

The bad news is that you have lost any programs that were on that Wombat.
Warranty should cover repair if you've had it for so little time

If anyone wants to try python3 on the Wombat (beta test), 
open a terminal (use ssh or hide UI->root terminal) and do:
```sh
cd /home/pi

#Install the modified harrogate
sudo rm -r harrogate
git clone https://github.com/kipr/harrogate --branch python3
cd harrogate
sudo killall node
sudo gulp

#If this launches the server or holds up the terminal, just do CTRL+C to exit. 
#Don't worry if it says it crashed, this is just for compilation.

#Install libwallaby
cd /home/pi
mkdir dev
cd dev
git clone https://github.com/kipr/libwallaby --branch python3
cd libwallaby
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
sudo make -j4
sudo make install

reboot
#select 1
#password is wallaby
```
If you update the Wombat, all of this will get reverted.

I know this solution sucks, I am still working with the engineers at iRobot to get a better solution. This is just a quick fix I found.

I'm currently working on a fix for that, the best solution I have found so far is to
1) Take the wheel modules out with the 3 brass screws (3 each).
2) Then unscrew the 3 silver screws on the back to pull the two plastic pieces apart
3) Disconnect the spring carefully
4) Use any kind of tape to tape the lever sensor found screwed into the plastic (it doesn't have to be tape, just find a way to keep it held down).
5) Put the spring back on the 2 hooks located on the plastic and on the motor/wheel assembly.
6) Put the plastic pieces back together and screw the 3 silver screws back. Then Screw the motor module back into the Create using the brass screws.

This will effectively make the Create ignore the wheel sensors, and since I can't think of a reason why someone would ever use the wheel drop functions in botball it shouldn't cause any issues.

I'm not sure if "cd ../.." is acceptable on Windows, so you may need to do "cd .." twice

Okay so first you probably don't want to be in system32, so do:
```bash
cd ../..
cd Users
dir #find which of those folders is your profile
cd (profile folder)
cd Desktop #or Documents or whatever folder you want
dir #make sure that you are in the folder you want to do this in (just a spare area you don't mind files downloading to)
git clone https://github.com/kipr/KIPR-Update
scp -r KIPR-Update pi@192.168.125.1:/home/pi #Copies the file over to the Wombat, scp is like cp but over network

#This will open a shell terminal that is actually on the Wombat
#It's the same as typing into a terminal on the Wombat but over Wifi
ssh pi@192.168.125.1
cd /home/pi/KIPR-Update #or cd KIPR-Update
sudo chmod 777 wombat_update.sh #Fix permissions so it's marked as executable
sudo ./wombat_update.sh

#After it finishes installing everything do:
cd /home/pi
sudo ./wallaby_flash
sudo ./zoobee_launcher.sh

```

gotcha

You need to go to the start menu and search for "disk manager" and then you will see all the harddrives on your PC.

Harddrives are split up into sections called "partitions", we will need to make the partition that has Windows on it (that takes up the whole drive) smaller.
To do that, right click on the box with the blue bar over it and click "Shrink Volume". If there are multiple boxes, send a screenshot to me so I can tell you which one to shrink.

You will have to pick a size to shrink to, you will want/have to pick a number larger than the amount of data you have on the drive already.
(ie, if you have 120GB/1TB, you shrink it to like 200GB or more)

After that, when you are going through the setup process, Ubuntu will ask you at some point to pick a drive, and setup partitions.
You will want to choose the option that says something along the lines of "setup my own partitions" or whatever (just don't use "guided" or "automatic")
Then make a new partition by clicking on "free space" and "+", "add", etc.
Make the mount point "/"
Make the file system "ext4"
You can choose to use all that free space, or leave some extra space for "Swap Area" (that the computer can use for better performance). 

It's also good to have Swap, which is space the computer can use for performance stuff.
It's best to make the swap partition at least 2 times the amount of RAM that you have.
For the rest of the free space you reserved, turn it into a swap partition (select "swap area" instead of "ext4" or "fat32" as the filesystem)

After that, the setup should be just reading prompts with what you want (I think it is just basic "new computer" setup after that)

Here are guides that explains the process step by step:
Easy but won't give *peak* performance: https://www.tecmint.com/install-ubuntu-alongside-with-windows/
A little more complicated: https://itsfoss.com/install-ubuntu-dual-boot-mode-windows/
